editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

figure.head: THE FRENCH LUCIAN MADE ENGLISH
figure.p: Sold by R Bentley in Couent Garden, 1693.

div.p: THE French Lucian, MADE ENGLISH; By J. D. Eq
LONDON, Printed for R. Bentley, at the Pot-Houe in Ruel-treet, in Covent-Garden, 1693.

div.head: To Lucian in Elyium.
div.p:
I Should injure Jutice if that after I have aumed an Idea which is properly Yours, I did not thereupon render you ome kind of Homage. The Author that upports us mot in our Writings, is the true Hero of the Dedicatory; his Praies we ought to publih with incerity, and chue him for our Protector. It may perhaps be • hought, that I have been very • old in daring to work upon your
Ground-plat; but it eems to me that I hould have been far bolder, if I had wrought upon • Ground of my own Imagination. I flatter my elf with ome hopes that the deig • being Yours, it will mak • way for what is mine, and thu • much I dare tell you, that if b • chance my Dialogues had an • o little ucces, they woul • gain You more Honour the • your own have, ince it would appear that this Idea is o taking that it matters not whether it b • duly executed or no. I depen • o fully upon it, that I thought • part of it onely would erve m •
turn. I have taken no notice of Pluto, Caron, Cerberus, nor of no one of the infernal Crew. How concerned am I that you have drained all thoe rare matters of the equality of the Dead, of their trouble at Life, of the fale contancy which Philoophers affect to make appear at their dying hour, of the ridiculous misfortune of thoe young people, that dye before the oldmen of whom they thought to inherit, and whom they o much courted. But when all is done, ince you had invented this deign, it was but just and reaonable that you hould pick and
chooe what was bet in it. I have at leat endeavoured to imitate you in the end you had propoed to your elf. All your Dialogues include their Moral, and I make all my Dead moralize, otherwie it had not been worth while to make them peak; ome of the living would have erved well enough to te • l frivolous things. Moreover, there is this conveniency in it, that a Man may uppoe the Dead to be perons of great Reflection, as well for their experience-ake, as becaue of their vacant time; and one ought to believe, that they think a little more then is
uual whilt alive. They dicoure of things here above better than we, becaue they behold them with greater indifferency and more tranquility, and they are willing enough to dicoure of them, becaue they till pretend to ome interest in them. You have made the mot part of their Dialogues o hort, that 'tis apparent you did not believe them to be great Talkers, and in this I can eaily agree with you. As the Dead are very witty, they ought to make a quick dicovery of the ending of all matters. I could believe too, that they might be eaily enlightened as to agree with
one another about every thing, and conequently that they hould carce ever peak; for I fancy that it belongs to us Ignorants only to dipute, who do not dicover the Truth; even as it is the property only of the Blind, who ee not the place they are going to, to jotle one another as they go along. But here we cannot be perwaded that the Dead hould have changed their qualities, o far as not to be any longer of contrary Judgments. When we have once conceived an opinion of Perons in this World, we cannot alter it. Thus I have made it my buines to make
the Dead known again, at leat uch as are mot eminent. You made no difficulty to uppoe ome, and ome of the Adventures too perhaps which you allot them; but I tood in no need of that Priviledge. Hitory did upply me with plenty enough of real Dead, and real Adventures, to dipene with my borrowing any aitance from Fiction. You will not be urpried, that the Dead do peak of what did happen a long time after them, you that do ee them entertain themelves every day with the affairs of each other. I am ure that at this very moment you
know France, upon a multitude of Reports that have been made you, and that you know that he is at this day in point of Learning, what Greece was formerly. Above all, your famous Tranlator, who has made you peak our Language o well, will not have failed to tell you, that Paris has had the ame eteem for your Works as had Rome and Athens. Happy the Man that could follow your Style as that great Man did, and in his Expreions lay hold of that fine implicity, and that natural pleaantnes, which are o proper for Dialogues! For my part, 'tis
far from my Thoughts, to pretend to the glory of having imitated you well; I deire none but that of having well known, that a Man cannot imitate a more excellent Model than your Self.

div.head: The Titles and Subjects of the Dialogues contained in this Volume.

list.item: I. ALexander, Phrinea. What Characters noie it mot. Page 1.
II. Milo, Smindirides. pon Nicenes. p. 9.
III. Dido, Stratonice. pon the Intrigue which Virgil does wrongfully attribute to Dido. p. 15.
IV. Anacreon, Aritotle. pon Philoophy. p. 21.
V. Homer, Aeop. pon the Myteries of Homer's Works. p. 29.
VI. Athenais, Icaia. pon the Fantaticalnes of Fortunes. p. 34.

list.head: Dialogues of the Ancient Dead, with the Modern Dead.
list.item: I. AUgutus, Peter Aretine. pon Praies. p. 40.
II. Sapho, Laura. Whether it has been well ordered, that Men hould attack, and the Women deend themelves. p. 51.
III. Socrates, Montaigne. Whether the Ancients have had more Vertue than We. p. 57.
IV. The Emperor Adrian, Margarite of Autria. What Deaths are the mot Generous. p. 66.
V. Eraitrates, Herveus. Of what ue are the Dicoveries, the Modern have made in Natural Caues, and in Phyick. p. 78.
VI. Berenice, Comus Medicis the Second. pon the Immortality of Name. p. 85.

list.head: Dialogues of the Modern Dead.
list.item: I. ANne of Britanny, Mary of England. A Comparion betwixt Ambition and Love. p. 92.
II. Charles V. Eramus. If there is any thing wherein Man may glory. p. 102.
III. Elizabeth of England, The Duke of Alenzon. Upon the little Solidity of Pleaures. p. 110.
IV. William Cabetan, Albert Frederick of Brandebourg. pon Folly. p. 116.
V. Agnes Sorel, Roxelana. Upon the Power of Women. p. 123.
VI. Jane I. of Naples, Anelm. Upon Diquiet for Time to come. p. 132.

sp.speaker: Phrinea.
sp.p:
YOU may know it of all the Thebanes that lived in in my time. They will tell you that I offered them to rebuild at my own charges the
Walls of Thebes; which you had beaten down, upon condition they would put this Incription upon them. Alexander the Great did beat down thee Walls, but Phrinea the Courtian has raied them up again.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: You were afraid then that future Ages hould not know what Trade you had driven?

sp.speaker: Phrin.
sp.p: I tell you I had been excellent at it; and all perons that are extraordinary in any Profeion whatever, are poeed with this folly of Monuments and Incriptions.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
'Tis true that Rhodopea had this humour before you. Her Beauty gained her o much money, that with it he built one of thoe famous Pyramids in Egypt which are tanding to this day; and I remember that as he was peaking of it the other day to
ome dead French Ladies, who pretended to have been very lovely, thee Shadows began to weep, aying, that in the Age and Country where they had lately lived, Beauties did not now make advantages whereby to raie Pyramids.

sp.speaker: Phrin.
sp.p: But for my part, I had that advantage above Rhodopea, that in raiing up again the Walls of Thebes, I made my elf equal to you, who had been the greatet Conquerour in the World, and made it appear that my Beauty was able to repair what your Valour had detroyed.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Thee are two things which certainly did never enter into comparion with one another. You are pleaed with your elf then, that you have been o Gallanted.

sp.speaker: Phrin.
sp.p:
And you, you are very
well atisfied that you have made deolate the better part of the World? Why was there not a Phrinea in each Town which you detroyed! There hould have remained no igns of your furies.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Were I to live again, I would again be a famous Conquerour.

sp.speaker: Phrin.
sp.p:
And I would be a lovely Conquerour. Beauty has a natural right to command Men, and Valour has but a right gained by force. Beauties have a right in all Countries, o have not Kings nor Conquerours. But yet the better to convince you, Philip your Father was a very valiant man, o were you too, however you would neither of you work any fear into Demothenes the Oratour, who, whilt he lived, did nothing but inveigh againt you both; and another Phrinea, far
beyond me (for the name is lucky) being likely to loe a Suit in Law of conequence, her Lawyer, who in vain had poken his bet for her, bethought himelf of putting by a great Veil, which partly covered her, and preently upon the ight of her beauty, the Judges who were jut going to cat her, chang'd their minds. So the noie of your Arms could not in a long run of years ilence an Oratour, and the attractives of a fair Creature did, in a moment, corrupt all Areopagus with its everity.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Though you have called another Phrinea to your aitanc, I do not believe that Alexanders Party is at all the weaker. It would be very ad if.....

sp.speaker: Phrin.
sp.p:
I know what you are going to ay to me. Graecia, Aia, Peria, the Indies, all thee make a fine hew: Yet, if I hould withdraw
from your glory, what does not belong to you upon that core; if I did give to your Souldiers, to your Captains, to Chance it elf, the hare belonging to them, don't you think you would be a loer by it? But a Fair Lady never hares with any one the honour of her Conquets, all is her own. Believe me, the condition of a pretty Woman is a pretty condition.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: It has appeared that you have been o perwaded. But do you think this part reaches o far as you have puhed it?

sp.speaker: Phrin.
sp.p:
No, no, for I am eay of belief. I confes I have, in an high degree, injured the Character of a pretty Woman, but you hove done as much by that of a Great Man. You and I have conquered too much. If I had been contented with two or three Gallantries
at the mot, I had not been irregular, and no exceptions could have been taken; but to have been galanted to that degree as to have had wherewithall to rebuild the Walls of Thebes, that was indeed too too much. On the other ide, if you had conquered Greece only, the neighbouring Ilands, and ome little part too perhaps of the Leer Aia, and made up a State of them for your elf, nothing had been more reaonable; but to run on till without knowing whither, and be always taking of Towns, and know not why, and always upon execution, without deign, 'tis that that was not approved of by many judicious perons.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Let thoe judicious perons ay what they will. If I had made ue of my valour and good fortune with o much dicretion,
there would carce have been any talk of me.

sp.speaker: Phrin.
sp.p: Nor of me neither, if I had been too dicreet in the management of my Beauty. When one will make a noie only, thoe qualities which eem mot reaonable are not the fittet for that purpoe.

sp.speaker: Smindirides.
sp.p: THou art very proud then, Milo, of having carried an Ox on thy houlders, at the Olimpick Games.

sp.speaker: Milo.
sp.p:
For certain it was a very brave action. All Greece did applaud it, and the honour of it reached as far as the City of Crotona my native Country, which has afforded an infinite number of tout luty men. On the contrary, thy City of Sibaris will be cried down to eternity becaue of the effeminacy of her Inhabitants, who banihed all Cocks from their Town, let they hould
be wakened by them; and when they made any invitation to perons, they invited them a year before-hand, that they might have the more leaure to make their Treat with as much daintines as they would themelves.

sp.speaker: Smin.
sp.p: Thou jeeret the Sibarits; but thou gros Crotonian, dot not thou think that in boating to have carried an Ox is not to be very like them?

sp.speaker: Milo.
sp.p: And thou, dot thou believe to have behaved thy elf Man-like, when thou madet thy complaint that thou hadt paed a night without leeping, becaue one of the Roes wherewith thy Bed was trewed, lay folded in two under thee?

sp.speaker: Smin.
sp.p: 'Tis true, I was o nice as that comes to; but why dot thou think it o trange?

sp.speaker: Milo.
sp.p: And how can it be but I mut think it o?

sp.speaker: Smin.
sp.p: What didt thou never ee a Lover, who being loaded with the favours of a Mitres, to whom he had rendred ome remarkable ervices, was troubled in the poeion of his happines, for fear that grateful acknowledgment hould work more in the heart of the Beauty, than her inclination?

sp.speaker: Milo.
sp.p: No, I never aw any uch. But what if uch a thing hould be?

sp.speaker: Smin.
sp.p: And didt thou never hear talk of ome Conqueror, who, at his return from a glorious Expedition, hould not be altogether atisfied with his Triumphs, becaue Fortune might have had a greater hare than either his Valour or his Conduct, and that his deigns might have taken upon fale and ill grounded Meaures?

sp.speaker: Milo.
sp.p: No, I never heard peak of any uch. But once again, what dot thou infer hereupon?

sp.speaker: Smin.
sp.p: That this ame Lover, and this Conqueror, and generally all men, although they hould lie upon Flowers, could not leep if one ingle Leaf only were foulded in two. A little thing poils a pleaure. Pleaures are Beds of Roes, where 'tis very hard to have every Leaf remain pread out, and not one to lie double; yet the foulding of one alone is enough to caue a great uneaines.

sp.speaker: Milo.
sp.p: I am not very much vered in thee affairs; but methinks, that thou, and the Lover, and thy uppoed Conqueror, and all of you together, are extreamly too blame. Why do you make your elves o nice?

sp.speaker: Smin.
sp.p:
Ah Milo! your Wits are not Crotonians, as thou art; but
they are Sibarits, more refined yet than I was.

sp.speaker: Milo.
sp.p: I ee well enough what the matter is. Your Wits, auredly, enjoy more pleaures than they need, and they let their nicenes retrench what they have too much. They are willing to have ome feeling of the leat dilikes, becaue there are other ways delights enough for them; and upon that account I find they are in the right.

sp.speaker: Smin.
sp.p: There's nothing at all of that. Your Wits enjoy no more pleaures than they need.

sp.speaker: Milo.
sp.p: They are fools then to make themelves o nice.

sp.speaker: Smin.
sp.p:
There is the michief of it. Nicenes does become men very well: it aries from the good qualities, both of the mind, and heart: Man takes a delight to have them, and he that wants them endeavours
for them; in the mean time, nicenes does leen the number of pleaures, and one is not overloaded with them. It makes them les enible; and pleaures, of themelves, are not over lively. How men are to be pitied! Their natural condition upplies them with few pleaing things, and their reaon teaches them to delight yet les in them.

sp.speaker: Dido.
sp.p:
ALas! how wretched am I, my poor Strationice! you know how I have lived. I was o exact in my fidelity to my firt Husband, that I burnt my elf alive rather than I would take a econd. However, I could not preerve my elf from being ill poken of. A Poet, Virgil by name, has been pleaed to change a wie Woman, o trict as my elf, into a young Goip, that lets her elf be taken with the handomenes of a Stranger the very firt day he ees him. My whole tory is quite contrary. To tell the truth, as to the pile of Wood
wherein I was conumed, I had right done me. But gues why I cat my elf into it? It is not out of any farther fear of being obliged to marry a econd time, but becaue I am grown deperate upon this tranger's leaving of me.

sp.speaker: Stratonice.
sp.p: Indeed, the conequences of this may be very dangerous. There will hardly be any more Women that will burn themelves out of a conjugal fidelity, if, after their death, a Poet may have the liberty to ay what he will of them. May be too, your Virgil was not o much in the wrong. Has he not cleared ome intrigues in your life, which you hoped would not have been known? Who knows? I would not anwer for you, upon the faith of your Pile.

sp.speaker: Dido.
sp.p:
If the Gallantry which Virgil does lay to me had any truth in it, I would be content to be upected;
but he allots me to be a Lover of Aeneas, a man that was in his Grave three hundred years before I came into the world.

sp.speaker: Strat.
sp.p: You ay omething now. Nevertheles, Aeneas and you, you eemed much to be a fit match for one another: You both of you had been forced to leave your Country; you both of you eeked a fortune in tranger Countries; he was a Widower, you a Widow: thee points agree well together. It is true, you were born three hundred years after him; but Virgil aw o many reaons to match you together, that he thought three hundred years difference betwixt you were of no conequence.

sp.speaker: Dido.
sp.p:
What an Argument there is? How three hundred years are not three hundred years, and in pight of that obtacle, two perons
may meet together, and love one another?

sp.speaker: Strat.
sp.p: Oh! 'Tis in that point Virgil did mean ome Cunning: Sure he was a man of the times: He would make it appear, that in matter of Love Concerns, we mut not judge upon Appearances; and that thoe that have the leat, are many times the truet.

sp.speaker: Dido.
sp.p: What had he to do to call my Reputation in quetion, by inerting this ine Mytery in his Works?

sp.speaker: Strat.
sp.p: But what? has he turn'd you into ridicule? has he made you peak impertinencies?

sp.speaker: Dido.
sp.p:
No, not at all. Here he has recited his Poem to me; and the whole piece where he makes me appear, is indeed divine, Couin Germain to detraction. In it I am all Beauty, there I peak rare things upon my pretended Paion;
and if Virgil were obliged to own me for an honet Woman in his Aeneid, the Aeneid would be the wore for it.

sp.speaker: Strat.
sp.p: What do you complain of then? you have a Gallantry put upon you which you did not enjoy; a great michance indeed! But, to make you amends again, you are et out for a Beauty and a Wit, which you were not.

sp.speaker: Dido.
sp.p: What a comfort!

sp.speaker: Strat.
sp.p:
I know not what humour you are of; but mot Women, if I am not mitaken, had rather have their Vertue a little quetioned, than either their Wit or their Beauty: for my part, that was my humour. A Painter at the Court of the King of Syria, my Husband, was diatisfied with me; and out of revenge, he drew me as in the Arms of a Soldier. He expoed his Picture to view, and
took his heels. My Subjects, zealous of my Glory, would have burnt this Picture publickly; but I being drawn admirably well, and full of Beauty, though the potures allotted me therein were not advantagious to my Vertue, I forbad the burning of it, and recalled the Painter, whom I pardoned. If you'll believe me, you'll do the ame by Virgil.

sp.speaker: Dido.
sp.p: That would do well, if the firt degree of Merit in a Woman did conit in being handom, or in being witty.

sp.speaker: Stratonice.
sp.p: I do not take upon me to decide what that firt merit is; but commonly, the firt quetion one asks of a Woman one knows not, is, Is he handome? next, has he any Wit? a third is eldom asked.

sp.speaker: Aritotle.
sp.p: I Could never have thought that a petty Ballad-maker would have dared to compare himelf with a Philoopher of o great repute as I am.

sp.speaker: Anacreon.
sp.p: You make the name of Philoopher ound very loud; but, I wih my petty Songs, have notwithtanding been called the wie Anacreon, and methinks the Title of Philoopher is not o good as that of Wie.

sp.speaker: Arit.
sp.p: Thoe who acribed you that quality, did not very well mind what they aid. What had you ever done to deerve it?

sp.speaker: Anacr.
sp.p: I had done nothing but drink, ing, and fall in love; and the wonder is, that I had this name of Wie given me for doing thus, whereas you had only that of Philoopher given you, which cot you a world of labours: For how many Nights have you pent in ifting the intricate Quetions of the Dialectick? How many great Volumes have you writ upon obcure matters, which perhaps you did not very well undertand your elf.

sp.speaker: Arit.
sp.p: I confes you have taken a more eaie way to attain to Widom, and you mut needs have been an able man to find out a way to purchae more glory with your Lute and your Bottle, then the greatet men have gained with their watchings and toyls.

sp.speaker: Anacr.
sp.p:
You think to jeer, but
I will maintain that 'tis harder to drink and ing, as I have ung, and as I have drunk, than to philoophize as you have done; to ing and to drink as I have, a man's Soul hould be freed from all violent paions, hould aim no more at what does not depend upon us, hould always be in a dipoition to take time as it hould come. In fine, there would be many little Affairs to regulate about him; and though there be no great matter of Philoophy in all this, one has trouble enough for all that to compas it. But a man may philoophize as you have done upon more reaonable terms. One is not obliged to cure ones elf neither of Ambition, nor of Covetounes; a man may have a favourable acces to Alexander's Court; he may purchae Pre
• ents of five hundred thouand
Crowns, which he does not altogether apply in experiments of Nature, according to the intention of the Donor; and in a word, this kind of Philoophy leads to things that are oppoite enough to Philoophy.

sp.speaker: Arit.
sp.p: Some body here below mut needs have poken ill of me to you; but when all is done, Man is not Man, but upon the account of Reaon, and nothing is more excellent than to teach others what ue they hould make of tudying Nature, and clearing all thoe Intricacies which he propoes unto us.

sp.speaker: Anacr.
sp.p:
Thus men pervert the ue of every thing: Philoophy in it elf is an admirable thing, and may be very erviceable to them; but becaue he would be uneaie to them, if he did meddle with their Concerns, and ettle her elf
among them to regulate their • aions, they have dipatched • er away into the Heavens to et • he Planets in order, and meaure • heir motions, or ele they pace • er up and down the Earth, to make her examine all they ee • pon it. In hort, they always • mploy her as far off themelves • s 'tis poible. In the mean time, • s they will be Philoophers at an • aie rate, they have the art how • o extend and et out this Title, • nd they give it for the mot part • o thoe that dive into natural Caues.

sp.speaker: Arit.
sp.p: And how can one give • hem a fitter Title?

sp.speaker: Anacreon.
sp.p:
Philoophy concerns • er elf with Men only, and not • t all with the ret of the World. The Atronomer mues on the • tars and Planets, the Naturalit • oniders Nature, and the Philoopher
thinks of himelf. But wh • would have been one upon uc • hard Conditions? Alas! carc • any body. Philoophers then ar • dipened withal from being Philoophers, and men are contente • they hould be Atronomers, o • Naturalits. For my part, I wa • not of a temper to engage myelf into Speculations; but I' • ure, that there is les Philoophy i • many Books, that make profeio • of treating of it, then in ome o • thoe petty Songs which you o much undervalue; for exampl • in this.

lg.l: If Gold length of life did betow,
Farther my ambition hould not go
Then greedily to heap up treaure.
When Death to me a viit made,
Quickly return would I bid her to her hade,
In giving her, what I had, without meaure.
But if Atropos and her Siters evere do not of this allow,
Gold hall no more be my care,
Shall my diverions make I vow.

sp.speaker: Arit.
sp.p: If you will call that Philoophy only which looks into Manners, there is in my Morals that which is as good as your Song; for that obcurity which I'm taxed of, and which is perhaps in ome of my Books, is not to be found in my Writings upon that matter; and the whole World has owned that there was nothing finer nor more clear than what I have aid concerning Paions.

sp.speaker: Anacr.
sp.p:
What an abue! The quetion is not to define Paions methodically, as 'tis aid you have done, but to mater them. Men willingly deliver up their Evils to
Philoophy for her to conider them, but not to cure them; and they have found the ecret of framing a Moral which reaches them no nearer than Atronomy does Can a man forbear laughing, to ee ome, that for money, preach up the contempt of riches, and Cowards that fall together by the ears about the definition of Magnanimous?

sp.speaker: Homer.
sp.p: ALL thoe Fables which you have now related to me, cannot, indeed, be admired enough: You mut needs have been indued with a great deal of art, that you could thus diguie • n little Tales, the mot important • ntructions of Morality, and cover your thoughts under thee Repreentations which are o proper and o familiar.

sp.speaker: Aeop,
sp.p: 'Tis very pleaing to me that I am applauded by you for an Art, wherein you were o carefull.

sp.speaker: Homer,
sp.p: I? I did never pretend to it.

sp.speaker: Aeop,
sp.p: How, did you not make it your buines to hide great myteries in your works?

sp.speaker: Hom.
sp.p: Alas! not at all.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: Nevertheles all the Learned of my time did ay as much; there was not a word in the Iliads, nor in the Odiea, but they gave it the finet Allegories in the World. They did maintain, that all the Secrets of Divinity, of Natural and Moral Philoophy, and of the Mathematicks, were incloed in your Writings. Truly 'twas omewhat difficult to dicloe them, and where one found out a Moral ence, another found out a Natural ence; but they agreed that you knew all, and had aid all to him that rightly undertood it.

sp.speaker: Hom.
sp.p:
Without lying, I did mitrut that ome ort of people would conceive I had ome cunning
meaning, where I intended none. As there is nothing like Prophecying things afar off in expectation of the event; o there is nothing like putting off Fables, in expectation of the Allegory.

sp.speaker: Aeop,
sp.p: You mut needs have been a bold man, to entrut your Readers with the care of putting Allegories in your Poems. Whereabouts would you have been, if they had been taken literally?

sp.speaker: Homer,
sp.p: Well then, the harm would not have been o great.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p:
What? thoe Gods who maim one another; that Thundering Jove, who in a Convention of Deities threatens to beat Majetical Juno; That Mars, who being wounded by Diomedes, bawls, you ay, like nine or ten thouand men, and does not act like one alone; (for intead of routing all the Greeks, he goes and
complains of his Wound to Jupiter) all this would have been well without an Allegory?

sp.speaker: Hom.
sp.p:
Why not? You fancy that the Minds of men eek for Truth altogether? Diabue your elf. Man's mind and falhood ympathize mot trangely. If you have a truth to peak, you'l do very well to fold it up in Fables, 'twill be far more pleaing. If you'l relate Fables, they may take without having the leat colour of truth in them. Thus Truth has need to borrow the hape of Falhood to be kindly received in the mind of man; but Falhood creeps into it well enough in its own proper hape, for that is the place of its birth, and its uual place of aboad, and Truth is there a meer tranger. Nay, I will tell you more than this comes to. If I hould have killed my elf to fancy
allegorical Fables, it might ve
• y well have happened that mot people would have taken the Fable, as a thing likely enough to • ave had been o, and would have • et the Allegory alone; and in
• eed, you ought to know that my Gods, uch as they are (and • ll Myteries laid aide) have not • een thought ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Ae.
sp.p: This makes me quake again: I am terribly afraid that it will be thought that Beats might have poken as they do in my Apologies.

sp.speaker: Hom.
sp.p: A pretty fear indeed.

sp.speaker: Aeop,
sp.p: Why what? If people have believed that the Gods could have held thoe Dicoures you made them hold; why will they not believe that Beats did peak in the manner as I made them peak?

sp.speaker: Hom.
sp.p:
Ah! the Cae is not the
ame; Men are willing enoug • that the Gods hould be as grea • great Fools as they; but the are not willing that Beats hou •• be o wie.

sp.speaker: Icaia.
sp.p:
SInce you will know my Fo •
tune, I will tell it you: T •• Emperour under whom I live had a mind to marry; and th •• he might the better chooe •• Empres, he caued it to be publihed, That all Women th •• thought themelves handom an • taking enough to pretend to th • Throne, hould come to Contantinople. God only knows what ••
world of people there was. I went thither, and I made no doubt but with my youth, my brisk eyes, and my way, which was pleaant and curious enough, I might not put in for the Empire. The day of the meeting together of o many pretty Pretenders, we all of us ran over in a ditracted manner the faces of each other; and I took notice with atisfaction, that my Rivals did look but with an ill eye upon me. The Emperour appeared; at firt he paed by everal rows of Beauties without aying a word; but when he came at me, my eyes were very erviceable to me, and they tayed him. Indeed, quoth he, looking upon me with a countenance uch as I could wih, Women are very dangerous; they may do a great deal of harm: I thought there was only a little wit to be ued in
the cae, and then I was Empres: and in the trouble I was in, what with hope, what with joy, I trove to make an anwer. In recompence of that, Lord, Women may do, and ometimes have done much good. This Anwer poiled all; the Emperour thought it o godly, that he durt not marry me.

sp.speaker: Athenais,
sp.p: Sure this Emperour was of a trange humour, to be o afraid of Wit, and 'tis to be preumed he had but little judgment in it, to believe that your Anwer did argue much; for to be free with you, 'tis no very good one, and you have no great matter to lay to your own charge.

sp.speaker: Icaia,
sp.p:
Thus go Fortunes; Wit alone made you an Empres, and an appearance only of Wit hindred me from being one. You were vered to in Philoophy, which is far wore than to be witty; and
notwithtanding all this, you married the young Theodoius.

sp.speaker: Athen.
sp.p: If I hould have had uch an example as yours before me, it would have frighted me. After my Father had made me a very learned, and a very godly Las, he did diinherit me; o ure did he make himelf, that with my learning and my fine wit, I could not mis of making my Fortune; and to ay the truth, I believed it as well as he. But now I ee I ran a great hazard, and that it was not impoible but I might remain without any means, and have Philoophy alone for my Portion.

sp.speaker: Ica.
sp.p:
No ure, but as good luck would have it for you, my adventure had not yet happened. It would be pleaant enough that upon the like occaion as that which befel me, ome other that knew my Story, and would draw
an advantage from it, were o crafty as to make no hew of wit, and that people would laugh at her.

sp.speaker: Athen.
sp.p:
I would not be anwerable for her ucces herein, in cae he were upon deign; but many times one does by chance commit the happiet Follies in the world. Have you not heard talk of a Painter who had o well drawn ome Bunches of Grapes, that ome Birds were deceived in them, and came and nibled at them? Do you judge what a Repute this gave him. But the Grapes were born in the Picture by a little Country Boy; and the Painter was told, That truly they mut needs be well done, ince they intied the Birds to them; but that the little Country Boy mut needs be very ill done, ince the Birds were not afraid of him. They
were in the right; Yet if the Painter had not over-een himelf in the little Peaant, the Grapes would not have had that prodigious ucces as they had.

sp.speaker: Ica.
sp.p: Truly, let a man do what he will in the world, he does not know what he does; and after the adventure of this Painter, we ought to tremble even in thoe Affairs, where we behave our elves well, and fear let we have done no fault that might have been neceary; all is uncertain. It looks as though Fortune took care to give different Succees to one and the ame thing, to the end he may always laugh at humane Reaon, which is uncaple of any certain Rule.

div.head: DIALOGUES OF THE Ancient Dead WITH THE Modern Dead.

sp.speaker: Peter Aretine.
sp.p: YES, I was a fine Wit in my time, and I made a pretty coniderable Fortune with Princes.

sp.speaker: Augutus,
sp.p: You writ then many Books for them.

sp.speaker: P. Aretine,
sp.p: None at all; I had a Penion from all the Princes of Europe, and that could not have been if I hould have ate writing of Praies. They had Wars with one another; when one had the better of the Day, the other had the better of it: it was not poible to give them all their Praies.

sp.speaker: Augutus,
sp.p: What did you then?

sp.speaker: P. Aret.
sp.p: I made Veres againt them: They could not be admitted into a Panegyrick, but into a Satyr they might. I had o well pread abroad the Terrous of my Name, that they allowed me Tribute to enable me to commit Follies in afety.

The Emperour Charles the Fifth, who you mut needs have heard peak of here below, being gone very unadviedly towards
the Coats of Africa, to receive an Overthrow, did immediately end me a Chain of Gold. I received it; and looking adly upon it, Ah! aid I aloud, this is but a mall matter, for o great a folly as he has committed.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: You had found a new kind of way to get money of Princes.

sp.speaker: P. Aret.
sp.p: Had not I caue to conceive ome hopes of a wonderful Fortune, in ettling my elf a Revenue upon the follies of others? It is a good foundation, and does yield well.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Whatever you can ay of it, the praiing Trade is uret, and by conequence the bet.

sp.speaker: P. Aret.
sp.p: What would you have? I was not impudent enough to praie.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Why? You were impudent enough to make Satyrs upon Crowned Heads.

sp.speaker: P. Aret.
sp.p:
It is not the ame thing to make Satyrs: it is not always neceary to undervalue thoe they are made of; but to give ome certain unrelihing praies, I fancy a man mut in ome kind contemn thoe very perons he praies, and think them great Cullies. With what face could Virgil tell you, that it was unknown in what quality you would rank your elf among the Gods; and that it was uncertain, whether you would take upon you the care of the concerns of the Earth, or whether you would make your elf a God of the Sea, by taking to Wife a Daughter of Thetis, who would willingly have purchaed the honour of your Alliance, though it had cot her all her Waters; or, in fine, whether you would quarter your elf in the Heavens, near Scorpio, who held the place of two
Signs, and who, upon your account, would have traitned himelf more?

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Be not urpried at Virgil's boldnes. When a man is praied he does not take take thoe praies in the trictet ene; he helps out the Letter, and the Writer's bahfulnes receives great eae from the elf-love of them to whom he applies them. Many times we imagine we deerve praies which we have not; and how hall we believe that we did not deerve thoe we have?

sp.speaker: P. Aret.
sp.p: You did hope then, upon Virgil's word, that you hould marry a Sea-Nymph, or that you hould have an Apartment in the Zodiac?

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p:
No, no. There is omething to be deducted from thoe kind of praies, to reduce them to ome reaonable meaure; but, to
peak the truth, the abatement we make is very little, and we take them at our own rates. In hort, let a man be praied in what manner you will, he will always take the advantage of believing that he is above all common praies, and that his merit did reduce the praier to go beyond all bounds. Vanity has diverity of Shapes.

sp.speaker: P. Aret.
sp.p:
I ee well enough, there mut be no difficulty made to puh praies to the heighth of exces; but, at leat, as to uch as are contrary to one another, how can one have the impudence to allow them to Princes? I will lay a wager, for example, that when you did revenge your elf of your Enemies without any hew of mercy, nothing was thought more glorious by all your Court, than to thunder out your fury upon every thing that had the Temerity to oppoe
you; but o oon as you had done any action that was mild, the face of things changed, and nothing was found in revenge, but a barbarous and inhumane Glory: one part of your life was praied to the prejudice of the other. For my part, I hould have been afraid let you would have given your elf the recreation to take me at my own words, and would have aid to me; Chue either Severity, or Clemency, to make the Character of an Hero: but when this is done, tick to your own choice.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Why, will you have one look o narrowly to it? 'Tis for the advantage of great perons, that all matters hould be problematical for flattery. Do what they will, they cannot fail to be praied; if it be for things that are oppoite, 'tis becaue they have more than one kind of merit.

sp.speaker: P. Aret.
sp.p: But what? Had you never no cruple upon you about all thoe Elegies which were heaped upon you? was there any need of training a man's wit, to perceive that they were intended to you? Praies do not ditinguih Princes; Heroes have no more than others: but Poterity does ditinguih the praies which have been given to different Princes. Some he confirms, and others he declares to be bae flatteries.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: You will then, at leat, yield, that I did deerve the praies given me, ince 'tis certain that Poterity has ratified them by her Judgment. Nay, in this cae, I have ome caue to complain of her; for he has o ued her elf to look upon me as the Model of Princes, that 'tis uual to praie them, by comparing them to me, and oftentimes the comparion does injure me.

sp.speaker: P. Aret.
sp.p: Comfort your elf: you will be no farther troubled with this caue of complaint. To hear how all the Dead that come hither do peak of Lewis the Fourteenth now reigning in France, 'tis he that will be looked upon hereafter as the Model of Princes; and I foreee, that henceforwards it will be thought that greater praies cannot be given them, than by allotting them ome reemblance with this great King.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Well then? Do not you believe that thoe to whom o great an exaggeration hall be addreed, will hearken to it with pleaure?

sp.speaker: P. Aret.
sp.p: That may be. People are o deirous of Praies, that Equality and Truth are dipened withall; and o are all requiite Properties.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: It's clear enough to be een that your aim is to exterminate all praies. If none but good ones hould be given, who would trouble himelf to give them?

sp.speaker: P. Aret.
sp.p:
All that hould betow them without Interet, 'tis their right alone to praie. How happens it that your Virgil did praie Cato o much, when he aid that he did preide in the Aembly of the • etter ort of perons, who are eparated from the others in the Eli
• ian Shades? 'Tis becaue he was dead; and Virgil, that expected nothing from him, nor from his Family, betowed but one Vere upon him, and made a reaonable • hought the bounds of his Elogy. How comes it that he poke o ill of you in o many words, at the • eginning of the Georgicks? You • llowed him a Penion.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: I have then flung away • great deal of money in praies?

sp.speaker: P. Aret.
sp.p: I am orry for it. Why did not you do as one of your Succeors has done; who, as oon a • he had attained the Empire, did by a Declaration, exprely forbi • the making of Veres for him a any time?

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Alas! He had greater reaon than I. Thoe praies whic • preent themelves to us are not th • true ones, but thoe are which w • natch up by the by.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: IT is true, the Mues had a hare in the Paions which we two have had, and they rendred them very pleaant: But this difference there is, you writ the Praies of your Lovers, whereas my Gallants did all they could to extol mine.

sp.speaker: Sapho.
sp.p: What then? the meaning is, that I loved as much as I was beloved.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p:
This does not urprie me, for I know that Women commonly are more tender hearted than Men. That which does urprie me is, that you hould let your Lovers know your inclinations
for them, and that you hould in ome manner work upon their heart by your Poeies. A Woman's part is but to defend her elf.

sp.speaker: Sapho.
sp.p: Betwixt you and I, • was a little troubled at it; 'tis an injutice that Men have done us: They have taken the aailing part, which is far more eaie than the defenive.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Let us not complain, we have our advantages. We that defend our elves, we yield when we pleae; but they that attack us, they do not always overcome, though they would never o fain.

sp.speaker: Sapho.
sp.p: But you do not conider that if thee Men do attack us, they follow the inclination they have to attack us: but when we defend our elves, we are not very much inclined to make a defence.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: Do you make nothing of the pleaure in eeing by o many weet Aaults of o long continuance, and o often redoubled, how they value the Conquet of your heart?

sp.speaker: Sapho.
sp.p: And do you reckon as nothing the difficulty to reit thee weet Attacks? they ee with delight the ucces of them in all their proceedings with us.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: But in fine, though after all their diligences, they become Victors in a fair way, you do them a favour in acknowledging them to be o. You can no longer make a defence, and they ceae not to let you ee the value they have for you, becaue you make no farther defence.

sp.speaker: Sapho.
sp.p:
Ah! this does not hinder, but that that which is a Victory for them, is always a kind of defeat on our ide. In being loved,
they have no other delight tha • that of triumphing over the peron who loves them; and happy Lovers are not happy but becaue they are Conquerors.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p: What? would you have had it ordered that Women hould attack the Men?

sp.speaker: Sapho.
sp.p: And what neceity is there, that the one hould attack, and the others defend themelves? Let both ides love one another as much as the heart will allow.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p:
Oh! things would run too fat; and Love is uch a pretty pleaing kind of Trade, that it was very well done to give it time to lat as long as it was poible. What would it be if one hould be entertained upon the firt offers? What would become of all thoe cares to pleae, of all that retlenes, when we tax our elves of ome neglect to give atisfaction,
of all that earnetnes wherewith we endeavoured for one happy moment? to conclude, all that delightful mixture of pleaure and pain, which is called Love? Nothing would be more inipid, if we did only exchange love for love.

sp.speaker: Sapho.
sp.p: Well then, if Love mut needs be, as it were, a Fight, I could rather wih that Men had been obliged to tand upon the defenive. And have not you told me too, that Women were more inclined to be tender hearted than they? Upon that core Women would attack them the better.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.p:
Ay, but they would defend themelves too well. When 'tis deigned that one Sex hould reit, 'tis intended the reitance hould be no more than would make the Victory better pleaing to the Victor, but not trong
enough to gain it. It ought not to be o weak as to yield upon the firt Aault, nor o vigorous as not to yield at all. Here is our Character, and 'tis likely it would not be the Mens. Believe me, when we have well argued the cae of Love, or of any other matter whatever, it is found in the end, that things are well as they are, and that the pretended Reformation would poil all.

sp.speaker: Montaigne.
sp.p: IT is you then, Divine Socrates! How glad am I to ee you! I am jut now arrived in this Country, and I was no ooner come hither, but I looked up and down for you. In fine, after having filled up my Book with your Name, and with your Elogies, I can now entertain my elf with you, and learn how you came by that Vertue, o Montaigne's Terms in French, downright, which had uch natural goings, and which could not be fitted with any example, even in that happy Age you lived in.

sp.speaker: Socrates.
sp.p: I am glad to ee a dead peron that eems to me to have been a Philoopher; but you being lately come from above, and I not having een any body here of a long time (for I am left lonely enough, and there is no great triving for my Converation) will you not be diguted if I ask you ome News? How goes the World? Is it not hugely changed?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Extreamly: You would not know it again.

sp.speaker: Socrat.
sp.p: I am glad of it at my heart. I did ever upect that it would of neceity become better and wier than it was in my days.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
What is your meaning? It is grown more foolih, and more corrupted than ever. That is the change I meant, and I expected to know of you the tory of the time you aw, and wherein
reigned o much goodnes and righteounes.

sp.speaker: Socrat.
sp.p: And I, on the contrary, did expect to hear wonders of the Age in which you have lately lived. What? Have not the Men of thee times corrected themelves of the follies of Antiquity?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: I believe 'tis becaue you are ancient your elf, that you peak o familiarly of Antiquity; but know that there is caue enough to lament its Manners, and that daily every thing grows wore.

sp.speaker: Socrat.
sp.p: Can that be? Methinks all went very cros in my days. I thought that in the end they would take a more reaonable coure, and that Men would better themelves by the experience of o many years.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
And do Men try Experiences? They are jut like Birds,
who let themelves be caught in the ame Net, in which an hundred thouand Birds had been already taken. There is not a Man that does not enter into Life all raw, and the follies of Fathers are of no advantage to Children.

sp.speaker: Socrat.
sp.p: But why do not they make ome Experiences? I hould think that the World ought to be wier, and more regular in its old days, than it had been in its youth.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Men in all Ages have the elf ame Inclinations, over which Reaon has no power at all. So in all places where there are Men, there are follies, and the ame follies.

sp.speaker: Socrat.
sp.p: And upon that core, how would you have had the Ages of Antiquity been better than this Age is?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Ah Socrates! I knew well enough you had a ingular way of arguing, and drawing o dexterouly thoe you had to deal with into Arguments whereof they did not fore-ee the Concluion, that you lead them whither you had a mind; and it was that which you called to be the Midwife of their thoughts, and bring them to Bed. I confes here I am brought to Bed of a Propoition quite contrary to that which I propoed; for all that, I cannot yield yet. Sure it is, there are no more any of thoe vigorous and turdy Souls of Antiquity, no Aritides, no Phocions, no Pericles, nor, in hort, no Socrates.

sp.speaker: Socrat.
sp.p:
Where does it tick? Is it that Nature has exhauted her elf, and has no farther trength to produce thoe great Souls? And why hould he have wated her
elf in nothing but in rational Men? None of her Works did degenerate yet; why hould men only degenerate?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: That is a point indeed; they do degenerate. Nature eems to have hewed us heretofore ome patterns of great men, thereby to peruade us, that he could have made ome if he had had a mind to it, and that afterwards he had made all the ret with neglect enough.

sp.speaker: Socrat.
sp.p:
One thing mind. Antiquity is an object of a particular kind, a far off, does add to it. Had you known Aristides, Phocion, Pericles, and my elf, ince you will put me in that number, you would have found in your Age ome perons that were like us. That which does uually caue this prevention in people for Antiquity, is, becaue they are out of humour with their
Age, and Antiquity takes advantage thereof. Men exalt the Ancients, to pull down their Contemporaries. When we lived, we eteemed our Ancetors more than they deerved; and now, our Poterity eteem us more than is our deert: but our Ancetors, and we, and our Poterity, all this is equal enough; and I believe the Spectacle of the World would be very tedious to him that hould look upon it with an eye of Certitude, for 'tis always the ame.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
I hould have believed that every thing was in motion, that all did change, and that the different Ages had their different Characters, as men had. And indeed, Are not ome Ages learned, and are not others ignorant? Are not ome plain and downright, and others again ubtil and crafty? Some are erious, and ome are
toyih: ome again are fine and quaint, and others are gros and dull.

sp.speaker: Socrat.
sp.p: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Why hall there not be then ome Ages more vertuous, and others more wicked?

sp.speaker: Socrat.
sp.p:
That is no conequence. Cloaths change; but by that it is not meant that the Bodies change their form too: The neatnes or the grones, the knowledge or the ignorance, the more or les of a certain kind of downrightnes, the erious or the toyih Genius; thee make but the out-ide of Man, and all this does change; but the heart does not change, and whole Man conits in the heart. People are ignorant in one Age, but the mode to be learned may come: People are intereted, but the mode to be di-intereted will never come. Of the prodigious
number of Men unreaonable enough that are born in an hundred years, Nature, may be, has two or three dozen of them that are reaonable, which he mut dipere over the whole Earth; and you judge well enough, that there are never in no place o many as may make a mode there of Vertue and of Righteounes.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Is this ditribution of rational men equally made? There might have been ome Ages that might have had a better hare than others.

sp.speaker: Socrat.
sp.p: Nature does ever act very regularly, but we do not judge as he acts.

div.head: The Fourth Dialogue.
div.stage: Adrian the Emperor. Margaret of Autria.

sp.speaker: M. of Autria.
sp.p: WHat ail's you? I ee you are all in an heat.

sp.speaker: Adrian.
sp.p: I have jut now had a trong Contet with Cato of tica, about the manner how we both died. I pretended that in this lat action I had hewed my elf more a Philoopher than he had.

sp.speaker: M. of Autria.
sp.p:
I think you very bold, that you dare quetion o famous a death as his. Was there any thing more glorious, than to take care that all was well etled in tica, ecure his Friends, and
kill himelf, that he might end with the Liberty of his Country, and avoid falling into the hands of a Vanquiher, who would, however have pared him?

sp.speaker: Adrian.
sp.p:
Oh! if you did narrowly examine that death, you would find there were everal things to quetion in it. In the firt place, he had been o long in preparing himelf for it, and he did prepare himelf with uch viible trifes, that no body in tica made any quetion, but that Cato would kill himelf. Secondly, Before he gave himelf the blow, he was fain to read often the Dialogue where Plato treats of the Immortality of the Soul. Thirdly, The deign he had laid put him o out of humour, that, going to Bed, and not finding his Sword under his Beds-head, (for, as people rightly gueed what he had a mind to do they had taken
it away) he called one of his Slaves to ask him for it, and gave him o great a blow with his fit upon the face, that with it he truck out his teeth: this is o true, that he drew back his hand all bloody.

sp.speaker: M. of Autria.
sp.p: I confes, this blow with the fit does very much poil this Philoophical death.

sp.speaker: Adrian.
sp.p: You cannot believe what a tir he made about this Sword taken away, and how he railed at his Son and at his Servants; aying, that they had a mind to deliver him up to Caear, hands and feet tied together. In fine, he colded them all in uch a manner, that they were fain to go out of his Chamber, and let him kill himelf.

sp.speaker: M. of Autria.
sp.p:
Indeed, indeed, things might have gone on a little more mildly. He needed but have peaceably tayed till the next day to give himelf his death. Nothing
is more eaie than to die when one is bent upon it. But in all likelihood, the meaures he had taken upon the account of his contancy, were o exact, that he could tay no longer; and he had not, perhaps, killed himelf, had he delayed a day longer.

sp.speaker: Adrian.
sp.p: You ay right; and I ee that you have skill in generous deaths.

sp.speaker: M. of Autria.
sp.p: Yet ome ay, that after they had carried this Sword to Cato, and had withdrawn themelves, he fell aleep, and nored. That would be brave enough.

sp.speaker: Adrian.
sp.p:
And do you believe this? He had but done colding every body, and beating his Servants: a man does not o eaily fall aleep after uch an exercie. Moreover, his hand he had truck his Slave with did pain him too much to let him fall aleep, for he was
not able to bear the pain he felt: and he made it be bound up by a Phyician, though he was jut going to kill himelf. In hort, from the time his Sword was brought, till Mid-night, he read Plato's Dialogues twice over. Then I could prove eaily by a great Supper he made for all his friends, by a walk he took afterwards, and by all paages that happened till he was left alone in his Chamber, that it mut be very late when that Sword was brought him: Moreover, the Dialogue he read twice over is very long; and by conequence, if he lept, he lept but a little while. Truly, I am much afraid he did but make as if he nored, that he might have the honour of it from thoe that hearkned at his Chamber door.

sp.speaker: M. of Autria.
sp.p:
You do not play the Critick amis upon his death;
which, however, does carry in the bottom omething that is very heroical. But which way can you pretend that yours has the better of it? For as much as I can remember, you died in your Bed, in a plain and unremarkable manner.

sp.speaker: Adrian.
sp.p:
What? Are not thoe Veres remarkable at all, which I made as I was jut giving up the Ghot?
My little Soul, my dear Darling, Thou;
Going thou art, Girl; and whither, God does know.
Alone thou goet, naked, and all over quaking. Alas!
What'll become of thy pretty fooling humour, Las?
What'll become of o many pleaant frolicks, I can't gues.
Cato treated Death like a buines that was too erious, but you ee, I drolled with it: and herein it is that I pretend that my Philoophy went far beyond Cato's. It is not o difficult haughtily to out-brave Death, as it is to joak her in a careles manner; nor is it o hard a thing to receive her kindly when we call her to our aid, as when he comes when we have no need of her.

sp.speaker: M. of Autria.
sp.p: Yes, I grant, Cato's death is not o brave as yours; but, as ill luck would have it, I had not oberved that you had made thee mall Veres, in which the bravery of yours does conit.

sp.speaker: Adrian.
sp.p:
This is the way of all the world. Cato may tear out his Bowels, rather than fall into the hands of his Enemy: it is, perhaps, no uch great matter, if it be throughly examined; yet uch a
feat as that makes a vat hew in Hitory, and there's not one but is taken with it. Another may die fair and quietly, and be in a capacity to make drolling Veres upon his death, 'tis more than Cato has done; but this has nothing in it that is taking. and Hitory does carce take notice of it.

sp.speaker: M. of Autria.
sp.p: Alas! nothing is truer than what you ay; And I my elf that now peak to you, I have a death that I pretend is far before yours, and yet 'tis les taken notice of. 'Tis not, however, a downright death; but uch as 'tis, it exceeds yours, that does exceed Cato's.

sp.speaker: Adrian.
sp.p: How? what do you mean?

sp.speaker: M. of Autria.
sp.p:
I was an Emperor's Daughter. I was contracted to a King's Son; and this Prince, after his father's death, ent me
back to mine, notwithtanding the olemn promie he had mad • to marry me. After this, the contracted me to the Son of another King; and as I was going b • Sea to this Husband, my Ship w •• beaten with a terrible Tempe •• which cat my life into evide •• danger. Then it was that I mad • my elf this Epitaph:

q.l: Has two Husbands, and yet a M ••• does die.

sp.p:
The truth is, I did not die <…> , but 'twas not my fault. Co •
ceive well this kind of death, yo • be atisfied with it. Cato's Co •
tancy is injured in one kind, yo • in another, mine is natural. H • too high, you are too drolling am reaonable.

sp.speaker: Adrian.
sp.p: What? You tax me of having had too little fear of death.

sp.speaker: M. of Autria.
sp.p:
I do. It is not likely that a man hould be in no diorder at his dying hour; and I am confident you did force your elf then to droll, as much as Cato did to tear out his Entrails. I am every moment in expectation of Shipwrack without frightning my my elf, and I mak my Epitaph in cold blood; this is very extraordinary, and if there were nothing to moderate this Hitory, there would be ome reaon not to believe it, or to believe that I did act only by way of Rhodomantado. But in the mean while, I am a poor Girl, twice contracted, and yet have been o unlucky, as to die a Maid: I hew my Concern for it, and that gives my Hitory all requiite appearance of truth. Your Veres, mind them well, carry no
meaning with them; there is nothing but a Gibbrih, made up of • few Childih Terms; but min • have a very clear Sene, and giv • content at the very firt: which i • a ign that Nature peaks in them much more than in yours.

sp.speaker: Adrian.
sp.p: Truly, I hould neve • have believed, that the trouble to die a Virgin ought to have been o much • o your Glory.

sp.speaker: M. of Autria.
sp.p:
Make your el • as pleaant with this as you pleae but my death, if it may be terme • o, has another epecial advantag • over Cato's, and over yours. Yo • had both of you played the Philoophers o much whilt you lived that you had engaged your elve upon Honour, not to be afraid o • death: and if you had had the liberty to fear it, I cannot tell wha • would have come on it. But I, a • long as the torm lated, I had a
Right to tremble, and make my • ries reach Heaven, without any • ody's taking exception at it, or • aving a les eteem for me. Ne
• ertheles, I remained quiet enough • o make my Epitaph.

sp.speaker: Adrian.
sp.p: Betwixt you and I, Was • ot the Epitaph made on Shore?

sp.speaker: M. of Atria.
sp.p: Ah! this wrangling •• us is ill-becoming: I did not o • y you, about your Veres.

sp.speaker: Adrian.
sp.p: I yield then, in good • arnet; and I grant, that when • ertue does not go beyond the • ounds of Nature, he is very • reat.

sp.speaker: Eraitrates.
sp.p: YOU tell me wonders. What the Blood circulates in th • Body? the Veins carry it from th • Extremities of the Heart, and go • from the Heart into the Arterie which convey it back again towards the Extremities?

sp.speaker: Herveus.
sp.p:
I have hewed o m •
ny Experiences of this, that n •
body makes any further quetio • of it.

sp.speaker: Arait.
sp.p:
We deceived our elve • very much then, we Phyicians o • Antiquity, who took the Blood t • have but one low motion fro • the Heart, towards the Extrem •
ties
of the Body; and people are highly obliged to you, for having • bolihed this ancient Error.

sp.speaker: Herv.
sp.p: So I pretend. And people • ught too to be o much the more obliged to me, in that I was the firt that et them in the way to make all thoe fine Dicoveries, as are now made in Anatomy. Since I once found out the Circulation of the Blood, 'tis now, who hall find a new Conduit out, to convey the Blood into all parts of the Body; a new Reervatory? It • ooks as though whole Man were melted down again. Behold the advantages our Modern Phyick ought to have above yours. You made it your buines to cure the Body of Man, and his Body was altogether unknown to you.

sp.speaker: Erait.
sp.p:
I own that your modern Phyitians are better Naturalits than we; they undertand Nature
better, but they are not better Phyitians; we cured the Sick as well as they cure them. I could wih all thee modern ones, and you the very firt of all, had had Prince Antiochus in hand to cure of his Quartern Ague. You know how I went about it, and how • dicovered by the more than ordinary beating of his Pule in the preence of Stratonice, that he was enamoured with that beautifull Queen, and that his whole Dieae did proceed from his violent triving to hide his Paion • And yet I made o difficult and o coniderable a Cure as that was without knowing that the blood did circulate; and I am of opinion, that notwithtanding the help you might have received from this knowledge, you would have been very much puzled had you been in my place. The Point then in agitation
was not about new Conduits, nor new Reervatories, what was mot coniderable to be known in the Patient, was the heart.

sp.speaker: Herv.
sp.p: The heart is not always the Point in quetion, and all ick people are not in love with their Mother-in-law, as Antiochus was. I make no doubt but for want of knowing that the blood does circulate, you have let a great many people die under your hands.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.p: What? you take your new dicoveries to be very ueful?

sp.speaker: Herv.
sp.p: Sure enough.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.p: Anwer then, if you pleae a little quetion, which I hall put to you: What's the reaon we daily ee as many Dead come hither as ever did come?

sp.speaker: Herv.
sp.p: Oh! if they die, 'tis their own fault; the Phyicians are now no more in fault.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.p: But this circulation of the blood, thee Conduits, thee Pipes of Conveyance, thee Reervatories; all thee then are of no ue to cure?

sp.speaker: Herv.
sp.p: Perhaps men have not had pleaure as yet, to make any ue of all they have learnt of late but 'tis impoible but in time they'l fee great effects thereof.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.p:
Upon my word no hin • will change. See you? There is • certain meaure of ueful knowledges, which came early to men whereunto they have made little addition, and they will no • go far beyond it, if at all. The • are thus much obliged to Nature that he did very peedily inpir • them with what knowledge they tood in need of; for they ha •
been undone, if he had left it to the lownes of their reaon to find out. As for other things which are not o neceary, they are dicovered by little and little, and in a long run of years.

sp.speaker: Herv.
sp.p: It would be trange that having a better knowledge of man; man cannot cure him better: At that rate, why hould one go about to perfectionate the knowledge of the body of man? It would be better to let all alone.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.p:
There would be a los of very pleaant knowledges; but as for the utility, I think that to dicover a new Conduit in man's body, or a new Star in the Sky, would come to one and the ame thing. Nature will have men at ome certain times ucceed one another by the means of death; they have the liberty to defend
elves againt her till uch an appointed intant; but pat that, it will be to no purpoe to make new dicoveries in Anatomy, in vain will it be to penetrate further and further into the Secrets of the frame of man's Body; Nature will not be baffled, People will die after the uual manner.

sp.speaker: Comus of Medicis.
sp.p:
SOme learned Perons lately deceaed have jut now told me ome News that troubles me very much. You mut undertand that Galileus, who was my Mathematician, had made a dicovery of certain Planets that turn round about Jupiter, which, in honour of me, he called the Stars of Medicis. But I am told that they are carce known now by that Name, and that they are but plainly call'd Jupiter's Satellits. The World
mut needs be very wicked now, and very envious of anothers glory.

sp.speaker: Berenice,
sp.p: No doubt of it, I eldom knew more remarkable effects of its malignity.

sp.speaker: C. Medicis,
sp.p:
You peak of it with little concern, after the good luck you have had. You had made a Vow that you would cut off your hair if your Huband Ptolom •
came back victorious from I can not tell—what War. He returned having defeated his Enemies; you Conecrated your hai • in the Temple of Venus, and th • next day a Mathematician made i • diappear, and publickly declared, that they had been change • into a Contellation, which h • called Berenices Locks. To mak • Stars pas for a Womans hair, tha • was far wore than to give Prince his Name to new Planet •
however your hair has had ucces, and thoe poor Stars call'd Medicis, could not have the like Fortune.

sp.speaker: Berenice,
sp.p: If I could give you my Celetial hair, I would give it to comfort you; and I hould withal be o generous as not to pretend that you hould be much obliged to me for that preent.

sp.speaker: C. Medicis,
sp.p: It would be coniderable though, and I wih my Name were as ure to live as yours is.

sp.speaker: Berenice,
sp.p:
Alas! in cae all the Contellations hould bear my Name, hould I be the better for it? It would be above in the Heavens, and I my elf, I hould be till here below. Men are pleaant, they cannot teal away from Death themelves, and they trive to rob her of two or three Syllables that belongs to them. This is a pretty
Cheat they think to put upon her. Were it not better they would in an handom way conent to die, they and their Names too?

sp.speaker: C. Med.
sp.p: I am not of your mind: People die, but as little as is poible, and as dead as they are, they endeavour to faten upon life till, either in a piece of Marble which repreents them, by tones raied up the one upon the other; ay, by ones one Tomb. A man drowns himelf, and hangs on all thee Hooks.

sp.speaker: Berenice,
sp.p: Ay, but thoe things which hould preerve our Names from death, die themelves after their way. To what will you fix your immortality? A Town, an Empire it elf, can hardly be reponible to you for it.

sp.speaker: C. Medicis,
sp.p: The invention of giving ones Name to Stars, is not bad; they lat forever.

sp.speaker: Berenice,
sp.p:
Yet after the manner as I hear people talk, the Stars too are liable to fail: They ay new ones come, and ancient ones go away; and you will ee that at length I hall not have one ingle hair perhaps remaining in the Sky. At leat that which cannot be wanting to our Names, is as I may ay, a Grammatical death; ome changes in the Letters does put them in a condition to be of no farther ue than to intangle the Learned. It is not long ince I aw here below two dead perons, who had a very hot Contet with one another. I drew near, I asked who they were; and I was told that the one was the great Constantine, and the other a Barbarian Emperour. Their Dipute was about
the preference of their pat Greatnes. Contantine aid, he had been Emperour of Contantinople; and the Barbarian that he had been o of Stambole. The firt aid, to et out his Contantinople, that it was eated upon three Seas, upon the Euxin, upon the Bophorus of Thracia, and upon the Propontides. The other replyed, that Stambole did alo command three Seas, The black Sea, the treight, and the Sea Marmara. This relation of Contantinople and Stambole did put Contantine into a maze; but after he had exactly informed himelf of the ituation of Stambole, he was yet more amazed, to find that it was Contantinople, which he could not know again, becaue of the change of Names. Alas! aid he aloud, I hould have done as well to have left Contantinople her firt Name
of Bizantium. Who'l find out the Name of Contantine in Stambole? He will indeed find there what he looks for.

sp.speaker: C. Medicis,
sp.p: In earnet, you comfort me a little, and I am reolved to have patience. When all is done, ince we could not chooe but die, it is pretty reaonable that our Names hould die too; they are of no better quality then we.

div.head: The Firt Dialogue.
div.stage: Anne of Britany. Mary of England.

sp.speaker: Anne of Britany.
sp.p:
FOR certain, my death did you a great kindnes: you, immediately upon it, croed the Sea to go and marry Lewis XII. and eize upon the Throne which I left empty for you. But you enjoyed it but a while, and I was revenged of you by means of your
youth and beauty, which rendred you too too lovely in the King's eye; and, with overmuch facility, did comfort him in his los of me; for they hatned his death, and hindred you from being Queen long.

sp.speaker: Mary of England,
sp.p: Truly, Royalty did but jut hew it elf to me, and preently diappeared.

sp.speaker: Anne of Brit.
sp.p: And after this, you became Dutches of Suffolk. A fair fall. For my part, Heaven be thanked, I have had another detiny. When Charles VIII. died, I did not loe my place by his death, and I married his Succeor; which is an example of a very ingular happines.

sp.speaker: Mary of Engl.
sp.p: Would you believe me, if I did tell you, that I never bore you any grudge for that happines.

sp.speaker: Anne of Brit.
sp.p: No. I apprehend too well what it is to be Dutches of Suffolk, having firt been Queen of France.

sp.speaker: Mary of Engl.
sp.p: But I loved the Duke of Suffolk.

sp.speaker: Anne of Brit.
sp.p: That's nothing After one has once tated the weetnes of Royalty, is it poible to relih any other?

sp.speaker: Mary of Engl.
sp.p: It is, provided they be of love. I do aure you that you ought not to wih me il • for having ucceeded you. If, al • along, I could have dipoed o • my elf, I hould have been but • Dutches; and I made a peed • return into England, to take upo • me that Title, o oon as ever I wa • dicharged of that of Queen.

sp.speaker: Anne of Brit.
sp.p: Were you o lo • minded?

sp.speaker: Mary of Engl.
sp.p:
Ambition, I mu • confes, was of no concern to me
Nature has made ome plain pleaures for men, uch as are eaie and quiet, and their imagination makes them ome that are intricate, uncertain, and hard to come by: but Nature is more dexterous in creating them pleaures, than they are themelves. Why do not they commit that charge to her? She invented Love, which is very pleaing; and they have invented Ambition, which was needles.

sp.speaker: Anne of Brit.
sp.p: Who tells you that men did invent Ambition? Nature is no les buie in inpiring deires of elevation and commanding, than he is in working an inclination in men to love.

sp.speaker: Mary of Engl.
sp.p:
Ambition may be eaily known to be a work of the imagination; he is the very form of it: he is retles, full of chymerical projects; he has no ooner attained her deires, but he
out-goes them again. She aims till at a mark he never hits.

sp.speaker: Anne of Brit.
sp.p: And unluckily, Love has a mark which he hits but too oon.

sp.speaker: Mary of Engl.
sp.p:
That which enues hereupon is, that one may oftentimes be happy through Love, and one can be o but once through Ambition; or, if it be poible to be • , at leat, thoe kind of pleaures are made for no great number of perons; and conequently, Nature does not propoe them to Men, for her favours are always very general. Conider Love; 'tis made for every one. None but uch as do eek out their happines in a tate too elevated, do think that Nature has grudged them the weet delights of Love. A King who can make himelf ure of an hundred thouand Arms, cannot, perhaps, make
himelf ure of one heart. He knows not whether that which a man does for another peron, be not done out of a point of Honour. His Royalty deprives him of the inceret and the weetet pleaures.

sp.speaker: Anne of Brit.
sp.p:
You do not render Kings much the more unhappy by this inconvenience you find out in their condition. When a man ees his Will not only fulfilled, but prevented an infinite number of Fortunes depending upon a word, which he may utter when he pleaes; o many cares, uch a multitude of deigns, o much eagernes, uch an application to pleae, whereof he is the only object; truly it is a comfort to a man, not to know exactly, whether he be loved for his degrees ake, or for his peron's ake. The pleaures of Ambition, ay you, are
deigned for too few: what you charge them with, as a fault, is their greatet charm. In point of good luck Exception flatters; and uch as reign are excepted with o much advantage from the condition of other men, that though they hould loe omething of the pleaures which are common to all the world, they would till have more than they would deire.

sp.speaker: Mary of Engl.
sp.p:
Ah! judge of their los by the enibility wherewith they receive thoe incere and common pleaures, when any preent themelves. Hear what a Princes of my own Blood told me here, the other day, who has reigned in England, both very long, and very happily, and without an Huband too. She gave her firt Audience to ome Dutch Ambaadors, who had in their Retinue an handome young man. So oon as he
aw the Queen, he turned himelf towards ome that were near him, and poke omething to them oftly, but with a Countenance that made her gues pretty well what he aid; for Women are endued with an admirable intinct. Thoe three or four words of this young Dutch-man, whieh he had not heard, remained more in her mind, than the whole peech of the Am
• aadors: and, as oon as they were gone, he would needs atifie her elf in what he had imagi
• ed. She asked thoe to whom this • oung man had poken, what he had aid to them? They made her • nwer, with great repect, that it was what they did not dare to tell • gain to o great a Queen; and • orbore telling it a long time. In • ine, when he made ue of her • bolute Authority, he was told, • hat the Dutch-man had aid in a
low voice: Ah! this is an handome Woman; and had added ome groer expreion, but brisk, to hew that he liked her. They made the relation hereof with great apprehenion; however, nothing happened upon it, aving only, that when he dimied the Ambaadors, he made a coniderable Preent to the young Dutch-man. See how, among all thee pleaures of Greatnes and Royalty, this of being thought handom • did touch her to the quick.

sp.speaker: Anne of Brit.
sp.p:
But, in fine, he would not have purchaed it with the los of the other. Any thing that is too downright, is not fo • Man's turn. It is not ufficient th • pleaures do take with weetnes they mut agitate and tranport • man. How comes it to pas, tha • the Patoral life, uch as the Poet • decribe it, had never any Being
but in their works, and would not be liked of, if put in practice? It is too weet, and too too plain.

sp.speaker: Mary of Engl.
sp.p: I confes, men have poiled all. But how happens it, that the ight of the mot Majetical and mot pompous Court in the World has not the power to allure them, o much as the Ideas do which ometimes they propoe to themelves of this ame Patoral Life? meerly becaue they were made for it.

sp.speaker: Anne of Brit.
sp.p: In like manner, the haring in your plain and unditurbed pleaures, is but to enter into thoe Chymera's which men frame to themelves.

sp.speaker: Mary of Engl.
sp.p:
Not at all. If it be true that there are but few perons that can make uch a ditinction as to begin with thoe kind of pleaures, people are willing, at leat, to end with them when they
can. The Imagination has run over all fale objects, and he comes back to the true ones.

sp.speaker: Eramus.
sp.p: MAke no quetion of it: i • there was any uch thing a • place among the Dead, I would not yield you the precedency.

sp.speaker: Charles V.
sp.p: What? A Grammarian, one of Learning; and what is yet more, a man of Wit, would pretend to be better than a Prince that has been Mater of the better part of Europe?

sp.speaker: Eramus.
sp.p:
Put America to it alo, and I hall not fear you a jot the more. All this greatnes was, as one may ay, but a compoition of many hazards; and if one hould di-unite all the parts that make it up, you would ee plainly that it was o. If Ferdinando, your Grandfather, had been a man of his word, little would have remained to you in Italy. If any other Princes but he had the wit to believe that there were Antipodes, Chritopher Columbus would not have applied himelf to him, and America had not been in the number of your States. If, after the death of the lat Duke of Burgundy, Lewis XI. had minded what he did, Maximilian had not had the Heires of Burgundy, nor you had not had the Low-Countries. If Henry of Catyle, Brother to your Grandmother Iabella, had not had
