an ill Reputation among Women, or if his Wifes Honety had not been omething quetionable, Henry's Daughter had paed for her Daughter, and you would have mied the Kingdom of Catille.

sp.speaker: Charles V.
sp.p: You make me tremble. I fancy now at this very moment, that I am loing either Catille, or the Low-Countries, America or Italy.

sp.speaker: Eramus.
sp.p: Mock not. You would find it a task to make the one a little more olid, and the other omewhat more faithful. Take all, to the very impotency of you • Great Uncle, or the pertnes of your Great A • nt, and you will find, that it will be but neceary for you. See what a brittle building that is, which is founded upon o many things depending upon hazard.

sp.speaker: Charles V.
sp.p: Indeed it is not poible to withtand o trict an Examination as is yours. I mut needs confes, that all my Greatnes, and all my Titles do diappear in your preence.

sp.speaker: Eramus.
sp.p:
Thee are the qualities though you pretended to adorn your elf with all; I have tript you of them without any trouble. Do not you remember you have heard ay, that Cimon the Athenian, having taken everal Perians Prioners, did expoe to Sale, on one ide the Cloaths, and their Bodies quite naked on the other; and that whereas the Cloaths were extraordinarily rich, there was great crowding to buy them; but as to the men, no body would meddle with them. In good earnet, I am apt to believe, that what did happen to thee Perians, would be the lot of many
an one, if there hould be a eparation made of the peronal Merit from that which Fortune has betowed upon them.

sp.speaker: Charles V.
sp.p: But what is this ame peronal Merit?

sp.speaker: Eramus.
sp.p: Is that a Quetion to be asked? All that is within us. The Mind, for example, Sciences.

sp.speaker: Charles V.
sp.p: And one may lawfully glory in them?

sp.speaker: Eramus.
sp.p: No doubt of it, the benefits of Fortune, as Gentility or Riches, are not it.

sp.speaker: Charles V.
sp.p:
What you ay, urpries me. Does not Sciences come to the Learned, as Riches do to the mot part of uch as are rich? Is it not by way of Succeion? You learned men, you inherit of the Antients, as we do of our Fathers. If all we enjoy was bequeathed unto us, all that you know was bequeathed to you alo.
And 'tis that which makes many learned men look upon what they have received from the Ancients, with the ame repect as ome perons do upon the Lands and the Houes of their Ancetors, wherein they would be loth to make any alteration.

sp.speaker: Eramus.
sp.p: But the Great Ones are born • Heirs to their Fathers Greatnes, and the Learned were not born Heirs to the Knowledge of the Ancients. Learning is not a Succeion that Man receives, it is a new Acquiition which he undertakes to make; or if it be a Succeion, it is hard enough to come by, though it be very honourable.

sp.speaker: Charles V.
sp.p:
Well then; et the labour there is to gain the Goods of the mind, againt that a man meets with to preerve the Goods of Fortune, then all is equal; for,
in fine, if you regard difficulty alone, 'tis certain the concerns of the World have more in them, than the peculations of the Cabinet have.

sp.speaker: Eramus.
sp.p: But let us not talk of Learning, let us tick to the mind; that advantage does no ways depend upon hazard.

sp.speaker: Charles V.
sp.p:
It does not depend upon hazard? What, does not the mind conit in a certain Conformation of the Brain? And is Hazard the les to be made of, for taking Birth of a well dipoed Brain, than if it were born of a Father that were a King? You were a great Wit; but ask all the Philoophers, what did hinder that you were not a tupified Block-head? Almot nothing, ome little dipoition of a Mucle-tring; omething, in fine, that the exactet Anatomy could never dicover.
And will thee Gentlemen, your Wits, dare to maintain, now, that they alone do enjoy Goods which are independent of Hazard; and they will think then, they have a Right to contemn all other men?

sp.speaker: Eramus.
sp.p: At your rate, to be rich, and to have Wit, is the ame Merit.

sp.speaker: Charles V.
sp.p: To have Wit is the more happy hazard; but, at the bottom, it is till an hazard.

sp.speaker: Eramus.
sp.p: All is hazard then?

sp.speaker: Charles V.
sp.p:
It is o, provided you will give that name to an unknown quality. I leave it to you to judge, if I have not tript men better yet than you did: you only took from them ome advantages of Birth, and I do not o much as leave them thoe of the mind. If before they took a vanity in any thing, they did make themelves ure, whether they had any Right to that
ame thing, there would be but little vanity in the World.

div.head: The Third Dialogue,
div.stage: Elizabeth of England. The Duke of Alençon.

sp.speaker: The Duke.
sp.p: BUT why have you flattered me o long with the hopes of marrying you, ince, in your oul, you were reolved to come to no concluion?

sp.speaker: Q. Elizabeth.
sp.p:
I have deceived many an one ele, that was not inferior to you. I was the Penelope of my Age. You, the Duke of Anjou, your Brother, the Arch-Duke,
the King of Swede, you were all my Suitors, that aimed at an Iland far beyond that of Ithaca, I kept you in hand everal years, and in the end I laughed at you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Here are in this place ome certain Dead, that would not yield that you were altogether like Penelope: but there are no comparions that are not defective in ome kind or other.

sp.speaker: Q. Eliz.
sp.p: If you were not as great a Buzzard till as ever, and that you could mind what you ay—

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
That is well; be erious now, I advie you. Thus you have ever made your Bravado's of—Witnes that great Country of America, which you made be called Virginia, in memory of a very doubtful quality. If, by good luck, that place were not in another World, the name it bears
would be very improper: but it is no matter, this is not the buines in quetion. Do o much as give me a reaon for your myterious Conduct, and for all thoe projects of Marriage, which came to nothing. Is it that the ix Marriages of Henry VIII. your Father, did teach you not to marry; as the continual Coures of Charles V. taught Philip II. to tay contantly in Madrid?

sp.speaker: Q. Eliz.
sp.p:
I might keep to the reaon which you upply me with. Indeed my Father pent his whole life in marrying himelf, and unmarrying again; in repudiating ome of his Wives, and cauing others to be beheaded. But the true ecret of my Conduct is, that I found nothing more pretty than to frame Deigns, make Preparatives, and execute nothing. Enjoyment of what a man does ardently
deire, abates of the eteem of it; and things do not pas from our imagination, to reality, without ome los. You come into England to marry me; then nothing but Balls, Feating, Rejoycings; nay, I go o far as to give you a Ring. Hitherto every thing miles as much as poible; all conits but in Preparatives, and in Ideas: Beides, that which does perfect the delight of Marriage, is already exhauted. Here I tick, and dimis you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: To be free with you, your Maxims would not have uited with me; I hould have deired omething more than Chymeras.

sp.speaker: Q. Eliz.
sp.p:
Ah! if men were debarred of Chymeras, what pleaures would they have left them? I ee well enough that you have had no ene of all the pleaures which attended your life; but you are
very unhappy indeed, that you did loe them.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: How? What delights were there in my life? I never ped in any thing. I was like to be King four everal times: firt of all Poland was the place in agitation, then England, and the Low-Countries; at lat, France, in all appearance, was likely to fall to me: yet, for all this, I am come hither without Reigning.

sp.speaker: Q. Eliz.
sp.p: And this is the happines you were not aware of. Always imaginations, hopes; and never any reality. You did nothing but prepare your elf for Royalty all your life-time, as I did all along prepare my elf for Marriage.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
But as I believe that a real Marriage might have fitted you, I tell you truly, that a real
Royalty would have pleaed me well enough.

sp.speaker: Q. Eliz.
sp.p: Pleaures are not olid enough to bear a earch into their depth; they mut be but jut melled unto. They are like thoe boggy Grounds, which a man is obliged to run lightly over, without ever ettling his foot upon them.

div.head: The Fourth Dialogue.
div.stage: William of Cabetan. Albertus Frederick of Brandebourg.

sp.speaker: A. F. of Bradebourg.
sp.p: I Love you the better for having been a fool as well as my elf. Tell me a little what your folly was.

sp.speaker: Cabetan.
sp.p:
I was a Poet of Provence, much et by in my Age; which caued my ruin. I fell in love with a Lady, whom I had rendred famous by my Writings. But he took uch a liking to my Veres, that he began to fear let I hould, ome time or other, apply them to ome other peron; and, the better to ecure her elf of the contancy
of my Mue, he gave me a cured Drink that turned my Wits, and made me incapable of writing any more.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.p: How long have you been dead?

sp.speaker: Cab.
sp.p: Near upon four hundred years.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.p: Sure, Poets were ever carce in your Age, ince people had o much eteem for them, as to poyon them in this manner. I am orry you were not born in my time; you might have made Veres for all kind of handome Women, without any fear of Poyon.

sp.speaker: Cab.
sp.p: I know it. I ee none of all thoe great Wits that come hither, make their complaints of having had my detiny. But you, in what manner became you a fool?

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.p: After a very reaonable manner. A King turned fool, after having had omething appear to him in a Foret. But what I aw was far more terrible.

sp.speaker: Cab.
sp.p: And what did you ee?

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.p: In what manner my Wedding was to be kept. I did marry Mary Eleonora of Cleve; and all along this great day of rejoycing, I made uch judicious reflections upon Marriage, that they put me out of my Wits.

sp.speaker: Cab.
sp.p: Had you any good intervals in your icknes?

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cab.
sp.p: So much the wore: and I, for my part, I was yet more unfortunate: I recovered my Wits again.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.p: I hould never have believed that that was a mifor • une.

sp.speaker: Cab.
sp.p:
When a man turns Fool, he mut be an abolute one, and
continue uch an one. Thee Alternatives of Reaon and Folly, and thee Returns again of perfect Reaon is the property of your petty Fools only, that are o but by accident, and which are but inconiderable in number. But behold thoe which Nature does daily produce in her natural coure, and wherewith the World • s filled; they are always Fools • n an equal manner, and are never cured.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.p: For my part, I hould have imagined, that it were bet • o be as little Fool as one could.

sp.speaker: Cab.
sp.p: Ah! do you not know the • e of folly. Folly hinders a man • rom knowing himelf; for the •• ght of his own elf is a ad one: • nd, as 'tis never time to know • nes elf, o folly mut not forake • man one ingle moment.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.p: You may ay what you will; you hall not peruade me that there be any other fools, than thoe that are o, as both of us have been. The ret of men have all Reaon; ele the los of a man's Wits would be no los, and one could not ditinguih the Frantick from uch as were in their right Senes.

sp.speaker: Cab.
sp.p:
The Frantick are only fools of another kind. The follies of all men, being of one ame nature, have agreed together with o much eae, that they have been intrumental to the making up of the tronget ties of Humane Society: witnes that deire of Immortality, that fale Glory, and everal other Principles, which give a motion to all that is done in the World. And none are called fools now, but ome certain fools that are, as one may ay, out
of employment, and whoe folly could not uit with that of the ret, nor enter into the common dealings of life.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.p: Thoe that are frantick, are uch great fools, that, for the mot part, they call one another fool; but your other men call themelves wie perons.

sp.speaker: Cab.
sp.p:
Ah! What is it you ay? All men point at one another with their finger, and Nature has very judiciouly etled that Order. The Solitary Man laughs at the Courtier; but to be even with him, he goes not to trouble him at Court. The Courtier laughs at the Solitary Man, but he lets him alone in quiet in his retirement. If there were ever a ide to be taken, that were known to be the only reaonable ide, every one would embrace that ide, and there would be too much crowding: it is better to be
divided into everal little Troops that embroil not one another, becaue ome laugh at what the other do.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.p: As dead as you are, I find you are a great fool with a •• your Arguments: you are not well recovered yet of the Drenc • was given you.

sp.speaker: Cab.
sp.p:
And this is the Idea whic • a fool mut always conceive of another. True Widom would too much ingularize thoe enjo •
ed her: but the Opinion of Wi •
dom renders all men equal, a •• does no les atisfie them.

sp.speaker: Agnes Sorel.
sp.p: TO tell you the truth, I do not undertand your Turkih Gallantry. The Beauties of the Seraglio have a Lover that need only ay, My Will is o; they never tate of the pleaure of Reitance, and they never afford him the pleaure of Victory: that is to ay, that the Sultans and their Sultanees do never enjoy the delights of Love.

sp.speaker: Roxelana.
sp.p:
What will you have? the Turkih Emperors, who are trangely jealous of their Authority, have, upon Reaons of Policy, neglected thoe o refined delights
of Love. They were afraid that uch Beauties as did not abolutely depend upon them, would aume too great a power over their mind, and meddle too much with Affairs.

sp.speaker: Agnes Sorel.
sp.p: Why, well, How know they whether it would be a misfortune? Love is often good for many things: and I that peak to you, if I had not been Mitres to a King of France; and if I had not had a great power over him, I know not whereabouts France would have been by this time. Have you heard in what a deperate condition our Affairs were in under Charles the Seventh, and into what a plight the whole Kingdom was reduced; the Englih being almot Maters of it all?

sp.speaker: Roxelana.
sp.p:
I have, as this Hitory has made a great noie. I know that a certain Maid did
preerve France: You are then the Maid? And how were you, the ame time, Mitres to the King?

sp.speaker: Agnes Sorel.
sp.p:
You mitake your elf; I have no concern with the Maid you have been told of. The King, of whom I was beloved, had a mind to leave his Kingdom to Strangers that were Uurpers, and go and hide himelf in a Country full of Mountains, whither I hould not have been very well contented to follow him. I bethought my elf of a Stratagem to divert him from this deign. I ent for an Atronomer, whom I dealt withal under-hand; and after he had made a hew of tudying my Nativity, he told me one day, in preence of Charles the Seventh, that all the Planets were Cheats, or I hould inpire a paion of long continuance into a
great King. I preently aid to Charles; You will not take it ill then, Sir, that I go over to the Court of England; for you will be no longer King, and you have not loved me long enough to fulfil my detiny. His fear of loing me made him reolve to be King of the French; and he began, at that very time, to re-etablih himelf. Behold how much France is obliged to Love, and how gallant that Kingdom ough • to be, though it were but by way of acknowledgment.

sp.speaker: Roxelana.
sp.p: 'Tis true. But • mut to my Maid again: Wha • did he do then? Could Hitory be o much mitaken as to attribute to a young Country Mai • that which did belong to a Cour • Lady, the King's Mitres?

sp.speaker: Agnes Sorel.
sp.p:
If Hitory hould • e o far mitaken, it would be • o great wonder. Yet 'tis mot certain, that the Maid did highly encourage the Soldiers; but I had • efore-hand animated the King. She was a great help to this Prince, whom he found ready to engage with the Englih: but, had it not been for me, he would not have found him in that poture. In hort, you will no farther quetion the hare I have in that great Affair, when you hall know the tetimony which was given in my behalf in this, by one of Charles the Seventh's Succeors, in this Quatrine.
Gentle Agnes, more Honour is thy due,
The Caue being France, for to recue.
Then what, in a Cloiter, can be done
By devout Hermit, or encloed Nun.
What ay you to it Roxelana? You will own, that if I had been a Sultannes; like you, and had not had a Right to threaten Charles the Seventh as I did, he had been undone.

sp.speaker: Roxelana.
sp.p: I wonder at the vanity you take in this petty Action. You had no difficulty to gain very much upon the mind of a Lover, you that were free, and your own Mitres: but I, as much a Slave as I was; I did, for all that, make the Sultan ubmit unto me. You made Charles the Seventh King, almot againt his Will; and I made Soliman my Huband, in pight of himelf.

sp.speaker: Agnes Sorel.
sp.p: But how? They ay, the Sultans never marry.

sp.speaker: Roxelana.
sp.p:
I grant it: However, I was reolved to marry Soliman, though I could not bring him to it out of hopes of an happines which he had not, as yet, obtained. I will tell you a tratagem that goes beyond yours. I began to build Temples, and to do everal other works of Piety; after which, I made hew of a deep Melancholy. The Sultan asked me the reaon of it a thouand and a thouand times: and when I had made as much a do as was neceary, I told him, that the caue of my trouble was, becaue all my good Actions, as our Doctors had told me, did me no good; and that, as I was a Slave, I did but labour or Soliman, my Lord. Hereupon Soliman made me free, to the end, that the Merit of my
good Actions might redound to my own elf. But when he had a mind to live with me as formerly, and treat me like a Beauty of the Seraglio, I made as if I were much urpried; and repreented unto him, in a very erious manner, that he had no Right over the Peron of a free Woman. Soliman had a tender Concience: he went to a Doctor of the Law, with whom I did deal under-hand, to conult about this Cae. His Anwer was, that Soliman hould beware of pretending any thing over me, who was no more his Slave; and that, unles he did marry me, I could be no longer his. Now he is more in Love than ever. He had but one Choice to make, but a very extraordinary one, and dangerous to boot for a Sultan: However, he made it, and married me.

sp.speaker: Agnes Sorel.
sp.p: I mut confes, 'tis a brave thing to make thoe ubmit, who do o fore-arm themelves againt our Power.

sp.speaker: Roxelana.
sp.p: Men may do as much as in them lies: when they are laid hold on by their Paions, one may lead them where one pleae. Let me return to life again, and let me have the mot domineering man in the world; I will handle him as I will my elf, o I have a great deal of Wit, Beauty enough, and but little Love.

div.head: The Sixth Dialogue.
div.stage: Jane the Firt of Naples. Anelme.

sp.speaker: Jane of Naples.
sp.p: HOW? Can you tell me nothing that is to come? You have not forgot all your former Atrology?

sp.speaker: Anelme.
sp.p: And how is it poible to put it in practice? We have neither Sky nor Stars here.

sp.speaker: Jane of Naples.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter. I will dipence with you, for oberving the Rules o exactly.

sp.speaker: Anelme.
sp.p: It would be pretty, that a dead man hould prophecy. But yet, upon what?

sp.speaker: Jane of Naples,
sp.p: Upon me, upon what concerns me.

sp.speaker: Anelme.
sp.p: That is a good one: You are dead, and will be o till: This is all I have to foretell of you. Is our Condition uch, that our Concerns may change?

sp.speaker: Jane of Naples.
sp.p: No. But yet, that is it which does cruelly trouble me: And though I know nothing will happen to me, if you would; for all that, fore-tell me omething; it would employ me. You cannot imagine what a ad thing it is, to have no time to come to look upon. Come; ome little Propheie, pray you, uch as you will.

sp.speaker: Anelme.
sp.p: To behold your retlenes, one would think you were yet living. Thus one is too above. One cannot be what one is there, with patience: we anticipate always what we hall be; but here we mut be more wie.

sp.speaker: Jane of Naples.
sp.p: Ah! Have not men reaon to do as they do? The time preent is but an intant, and it would be a pitiful cae, they hould be reduced to limit their fore-ight there: Is it not better they hould extend it as far as it is poible, and gain omething upon time to come? They poes themelves, however, of o much before-hand.

sp.speaker: Anelme.
sp.p:
But they borrow o much upon time to come, by their imaginations, and by their hopes, that, when it is preent, they find that it is quite pent, and make no ue of it. In the mean time, they do not break themelves of their impatience, nor of their retles humour. Mens great Lure is, Time to come till; and we Atrologers know it better than any. We boldly tell them, that there are cold Signs
and hot Signs; that ome are Male, and ome are Female; that ome Planets are good, and ome bad; and that there are others that, in themelves, are neither good nor bad; but they take upon them either of the two Qualities, according as they fall or light in company. And all thee flames are very well accepted of, becaue it is believed they lead to the knowledge of time to come.

sp.speaker: Jane of Naples.
sp.p: Why, do they not truly? I would have you that have been my Atronomer, tell me omething that is ill of Atrology.

sp.speaker: Anelme.
sp.p: Hear me. A dead man would not tell a lie: I did deceive you with this Atrology that you value o.

sp.speaker: Jane of Naples.
sp.p:
Oh! Herein I do not believe you your own elf. How could you have fore-told me, that I hould be married four
times? Was there the leat appearance, that a peron that was any whit rational, would engage in Matrimony four times one after the other? You mut needs have read it in the Heavens.

sp.speaker: Anelme.
sp.p:
I conulted them far les than I did your inclinations: but, after all, ome Propheies that fall out right, prove nothing. Shall I carry you to a dead peron, who will tell you a pretty pleaant tory? He was an Atronomer, and gave no more credit to Atrology than I did. Nevertheles, to try whether there was any thing of certainty in his Art, he did apply his whole care, one day, to oberve the Rules exactly; and did fore-tell ome particular Events in one peron, harder by much to gues at, than your four Marriages. All he fore-told did come to pas: Never was he
more urpried. He preently looked over his Atrological Calculations, which had been the Ground of his Predictions, know you what he found? He had made a mitake; and, if his Supputations had been right, he hould have fore-told the quite contrary of what he did foretell.

sp.speaker: Jane of Naples.
sp.p: If I did believe this were true, I hould be much concerned it hould not be known in the World, that they might undeceive themelves in Atronomers.

sp.speaker: Anelme.
sp.p:
There are other-guie tories than this known, and more to their diadvantage; and yet their Trade holds good. People will never be di-abued in any thing that concerns Time to come; it has too powerful a Charm. Men, for example, acrifice all they have to one Hope;
and all they had, and what they have lately purchaed, they till acrifice it to another Hope: and this eems to be a malicious Order, etablihed in Nature, to bereave them till of what they poes. Men do little care to be happy in the moment then preent, they put off being o to a Time to come, as though that time hould be of another Make, than this that is already come.

sp.speaker: Jane of Naples.
sp.p: No, it is not of another Make; but it is good to fancy it o.

sp.speaker: Anelme.
sp.p:
And what is the Effect of this fine Opinion? I know a little Fable that will inform you. I did formerly learn it at the Court of Love, it was a kind of Academy, which was held in your Country of Provence. A man was thirsty, and was at down by a Fountain. He would not drink of
the Water that was running before him, becaue he hoped, that in ome hort time better would come. This time being pat; This is till the ame Water, aid he, this is not that which I will drink of; I had rather tarry a little longer yet. At length; as the Water was till the ame, he tayed o, that the Spring happened to dry up, and he drank not at all.

sp.speaker: Jane of Naples.
sp.p:
As much as happened to me. And I believe that, of all the Dead that are here, there is not one who was not deprived of Life ooner than he had made the ue of it, he did intend. But what matters it? I reckon, the pleaure of fore-eeing, hoping, of fearing too, and of having before one a Time to come, to be great things. A wie man, in your Opinion, would be like we Dead, •• whom the Preent, and the
Time to come are perfectly alike: and this wie man would, by conquence, find it as irkome as I do.

sp.speaker: Anelme.
sp.p: Alas! Man's Condition is pretty, if it be uch as you believe it is. He is born to aim at all, and o enjoy nothing; to be always going, and arrive at no place.
